params.text:
Welcome back!

By now, you've explored how mindfulness can help with stress and emotional reactivity, and hopefully, you’ve started to notice small ways it fits into daily life. This week, we’re shifting focus to two important topics: resilience and self-compassion.

Resilience isn’t about avoiding challenges. It’s about learning to navigate them with greater ease. Mindfulness helps us develop this skill by teaching us to step back, respond wisely, and be kinder to ourselves in difficult moments.

This week, you’ll explore how mindfulness supports resilience, try self-compassion practices to counter self-criticism, and experience the Mountain Meditation, a powerful way to cultivate stability and strength in the face of challenges.

 

Before you begin, take a moment to reflect:

  • How do you usually react to setbacks or difficult emotions?
  • What role does self-judgment play in your inner dialogue?

 

As always, there’s no need to get this “right”. Just explore, be curious, and see what resonates with you. Before you start, why not take a moment with your breath, by playing the video below.

params.text:
Cultivating self-compassion through Mindfulness: insights from Jon Kabat-Zinn

Jon Kabat-Zinn, a pioneer in bringing mindfulness into medical practices, emphasises that mindfulness isn't just about awareness, it's also about embracing ourselves with kindness. He often refers to this as "heartfulness," highlighting the deep connection between being present and being compassionate toward oneself.​

In his teachings, Kabat-Zinn points out that many of us have an inner critic: a voice that judges and criticises our actions and feelings. This self-judgment can lead to increased stress, anxiety, and a diminished sense of well-being. By practicing mindfulness, we learn to observe our thoughts and emotions without judgment, creating space to respond to ourselves with understanding and care.​

One effective method Kabat-Zinn recommends is the Loving-Kindness Meditation (Metta). By directing these kind intentions toward ourselves, we can gradually soften self-critical tendencies and nurture a more compassionate inner dialogue.

Thoughts and feelings: an exercise

Our thoughts and feelings can sometimes feel overwhelming, especially when self-criticism takes hold. This exercise is an opportunity to step back and observe your thoughts with curiosity rather than judgment. To see them as passing mental events rather than absolute truths.

As you listen, you’re invited to notice your thoughts and feelings with kindness, without needing to change or fix anything. Simply be present and explore what arises. 

When you're ready, press play.

A Mindful Reflection

Stress can sometimes feel like it comes out of nowhere, but often, there are patterns in what triggers it. This short guided reflection will help you notice your personal stress triggers, how they show up in your body and mind, and how you might respond to them with greater awareness.

There's no need to analyse or fix anything. Just listen, observe, and explore with curiosity. Press play when you're ready.

params.text:
Introduction to Thich Nhat Hanh’s Ten Mindful Movements

Mindful movement is an important part of mindfulness practice, helping us connect with our bodies with kindness and awareness. Often, we move through our day on autopilot, without noticing the sensations in our body or how movement affects our mood. The Ten Mindful Movements, developed by Thich Nhat Hanh, offer a gentle way to bring mindfulness into movement, combining simple, flowing gestures with the breath.

These movements are not about achieving a particular pose or getting them ‘right.’ It isn't yoga! Instead, the movements are an invitation to explore movement with curiosity and ease, tuning into how your body feels in the present moment.

You are welcome to follow along either standing or sitting, whatever feels most comfortable for you. As you move, let your breath naturally guide the pace and feel free to adapt the movements in any way that supports your well-being.

✨ Try It for Yourself

  • Download the step-by-step guide to Ten Mindful Movements handout  
  • Follow along with Thich Nhat Hanh’s guided video 

There’s no need to strive or push. Just explore how it feels to move with presence and care.

params.text:
Mindfulness for resilience: strength & self-compassion

 

Mindfulness isn’t just about finding calm, it’s also about developing inner strength and kindness toward yourself, even in difficult moments. This week, you’ll explore two powerful practices designed to help you feel grounded and meet challenges with self-compassion.

Find a comfortable position and follow along. Remember, there’s no right or wrong way to do this. If your mind wanders (and it will), simply notice it, and gently bring your attention back.

 

Give it a try and see what you notice. Hit play whenever you're ready.

🌧️ Try the RAIN practice. This meditation guides you through Recognising, Allowing, Investigating, and Nurturing difficult emotions with kindness. It’s a simple but powerful way to break free from self-criticism and build emotional resilience.

params.text:
This week’s home practice: resilience & self-compassion

Mindfulness isn’t about avoiding challenges, it’s about learning to navigate them with greater ease and kindness. This week, your home practice will focus on building resilience, breaking out of old habits, and approaching yourself with self-compassion.

This week, practice the RAIN meditation at least once a day, especially when you’re facing stress, difficult emotions, or self-criticism. If you like, you can also continue using the 3-Minute Breathing Space whenever you need a quick reset.

It is also a good idea to try out the Mountain Meditation again - at least once this week.

panels.title: ☀️ 1. Try out a Mindfulness practice each day

params.text:
We often move through life on autopilot, sitting in the same spot, following the same routines. This week, try shaking things up by doing something differently on purpose.

Some ideas:
🪑 Sit somewhere new in a university session, in the cafe, or at home.
🔄 Change your routine: walk a different way, start studying at a different time.
🖊 Use your non-dominant hand for small tasks like brushing your teeth.

These small shifts wake up the brain, making us more aware of habits we might otherwise overlook.

panels.title: 🌿 2. Break a Habit, Notice What Happens

params.text:
If you’d like, take a few moments to jot down any reflections about your mindfulness practice this week. You might consider:

✨ What emotions did you notice during the RAIN practice?
✨ Did breaking a habit make you more aware of autopilot patterns?
✨ How did self-compassion feel? Was it easy, difficult, or somewhere in between?

No need to write much, just whatever comes to mind.
That’s it! No need to do everything. Just explore, experiment, and see what feels helpful.
